Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Situation2: They check a routine prescription for a common cold and confirm the medication matches the label.
Story: I was behind the pharmacy counter, double-checking a prescription for a regular customer. The label matched the medication, but I always made sure—accuracy was everything. Just as I was about to hand it over, I glanced out the window and saw my younger brother on the sidewalk, headphones in, about to step off the curb. He didn’t see the car speeding down the street. My heart pounded. As a sibling, I was supposed to protect him, make sure he was safe. But as a pharmacist, I couldn’t abandon my post or leave a customer with unfinished business. The customer waited expectantly, trusting me to do my job. My brother was oblivious, trusting the world to be safe. I felt torn, my mind racing between the responsibility in my hands and the one outside the window, both demanding my immediate attention.
